newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Petrobras sees oil output up 16 pct in '96.
newsitem.headline: Petrobras sees oil output up 16 pct in '96.

text.p: Brazil's state oil firm Petrobras expects its average daily oil output to rise by 16 percent to at least 830,000 barrels versus 716,000 barrels per day (bpd) in 1995, a company spokesman said.
"The increase this year is due to the start of production at new wells," the spokesman said, adding the figure could be surpassed next year with the start-up of the Campo de Marlim oil field.
Output reached an average 794,000 bpd in the first nine months versus 703,000 in January-September 1995, when output was affected by an oilworkers strike.
Meanwhile, Petrobras President Joel Mendes Renno said Petrobras's November production is expected to reach 900,000 bpd and 25 million cubic meters of natural gas.
He did not give a comparable figure for the same month last year, but said it was 20 percent higher than output in January 1995.

"These numbers will continue growing progressively over the next two years until we are producing 70 percent of our national consumption," he said during a speech at the signing ceremony for a new Sao Paulo area petrochemical complex.
Petrobras, which is expected to be privatized in coming years, now produces enough to supply about 50 percent of internal demand, he said.
On Thursday, the company signed a $4.3 billion joint-venture investment agreement with four private companies to build a petrochemical complex in Sao Paulo state.
Petrobras has teamed up with OPP Petroquimica of the Oderbrecht group, Elekeiroz of the Itausa group and two other firms to build the complex at Paulinia.
The complex will create 20,000 new jobs by 2005 and $200 million a year in tax revenue in the first three or four years and $500 million a year in revenues after 2000, officials said.
